HealthEdge: Company Overview
▪HealthEdgeSoftware, Inc. develops integrated financial, 
administrative, and clinical software platform for health 
plans
▪HealthRulesSolutions: is an enterprise class Core 
Administration Processing Systems
▪Patented, language-based technology platform, 
HealthRules®, is delivered to customers via the 
HealthEdgeCloud or on-site deployment. The 
HealthRulesproduct suite provides insurers with 
scalable, flexible technology that can either fully replace 
or augment legacy technology.
▪HealthRulesLanguage® (HRL): is an English-like 
language used for configuring Health Insurance contracts 
and policies
▪In addition, the company offers Account Management, 
implementation, and education services. 
▪Subsidiaries: AltruistaHealth, Inc., The Burgess Group, 
LLC
▪Blackstone acquired a majority stake in HealthEdgein 
March 2020
▪Established in 2004
▪1200+ Employees
▪90 Health Plan Customers
▪30Million + covered life
▪Location: 
US: Massachusetts, Virginia

4
HealthEdge: Key Offerings
▪HealthRulesPayor: is a modern core administrative processing system. It uses highly flexible, 
easy to read and understand, English-like language HealthRulesLanguage (HRL).
▪HealthRulesCare Manager:a solution that enables ACO’s, health plans, MCO’s, PCMH’s, 
Medicare plans, Medicaid plans, TPA’s, and pharmacy-related and specialty needs organizations 
to focus on prevention, care coordination, and patient engagement
▪HealthRulesAnswers:a business intelligence solution. HealthRulesAnswers enables real-time 
integration between all the components of the HealthRulesproduct suite
▪HealthRulesPortal: an integrated set of portals that enable communication with members, 
providers, employers, and brokers;
▪HealthRulesConnector:an enterprise-class integration layer that provides real-time and batch 
access to various HealthRulesdata and functionality.
▪Burgess Source®: is a Prospective Payment Integrity system. This solution provides network

access to various HealthRulesdata and functionality.
▪Burgess Source®: is a Prospective Payment Integrity system. This solution provides network 
configuration, pricing, and editing, along with a complete audit trail of all transactions
▪GuidingCare: solution spanning across care management, utilization management, population 
health, appeals and grievances, medication therapy management, member engagement, and 
reporting and compliance

HealthEdge: HealthRulesPayor Overview
HealthRulesPayor: is a modern core administrative processing system. It uses highly flexible, easy to 
read and understand, English-like language HealthRulesLanguage™ (HRL)
HealthRules Payor Platform
Designer
Manager
Administrator
Is used for day-to-day 
operations:
▪Enrollment
▪Billing & Payment
▪Claim Processing
▪Provider Relations
▪Customer service
Is used for configuring, 
building, and maintaining: 
▪Benefit Plans
▪Provider Contracts
▪Workflows
▪Business Rules
Is used by Administrators to:
▪Create Users & User 
Groups
▪Define Supervisors
▪Manage Permissions

19
HealthRulesDesigner
▪HealthRulesDesigner is the business rules authoring environment for HealthRulesPayor. It is 
used by the people in your organization that are responsible for configuration, and for the 
definition and maintenance of your benefit plans, provider contracts, and work flows. 
▪With HealthRulesDesigner, you use the patented HealthRulesLanguage, an intuitive English 
based language to quickly and easily read, write, and understand the rules that drive your 
business.
HealthRulesLanguage Example:
▪Benefit: Members who are being managed for heart disease should receive 100% coverage for 
the first $1,000 of cardiac preventative care and 90% coverage for additional preventative care.
▪Benefit in HealthRulesLanguage: Benefit for service category “Cardiac Preventative Care” and 
member with health condition of “Heart Disease” 100% of service cost until member receives 
$1,000 reimbursement within 1 calendar year then 90% of service

20
HealthRulesManager
▪HealthRulesManger is used for day to day  operation. The main HealthRulesManager functional 
areas are:
•Members (and Accounts) -This includes subscriptions, members, member accounts, 
member health conditions, accounts, benefit plans, compliance programs, and accumulator 
adjustments.
•Providers and Networks -This includes practitioners, suppliers, supplier locations, supplier 
networks, named provider groupings and tax entities.
•Claims -Claims processing for institutional, professional, and dental claims.
•Financials -Premium billing, accounts receivable, accounts payable and payment processing.
•Utilization -Service agreements and service authorizations.
•Others -Brokers, broker agents, broker contracts, reinsurers, and reinsurer contracts.
•Administration -IT administration functions such as maintaining business calendars and user 
accounts, data maintenance, lock management, and transaction management.

21
HealthRulesAdministrator
▪The HealthRulesAdministration Console is used by Administrators to create:
•Users and user groups
•Define supervisors
•Manage permissions
▪Users In HealthRulesPayor, a “user” is a person who uses any of the HealthRulesPayor 
applications (Designer, Manager, Administration Console). A user account must be created for 
each user. The administrator must assign each “user” a unique user name/password 
combination.
▪Groups A “group” is a record containing permissions settings and membership lists of users 
and/or other groups. Groups are used to control user access to the system through the 
assignment of permissions. Each user must be part of at least one group so they have the 
necessary permissions to access the application. 
▪Permissions “Permissions” enable you to manage user access to HealthRulesPayor actions (view, 
create, amend, etc.), claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.

▪Permissions “Permissions” enable you to manage user access to HealthRulesPayor actions (view, 
create, amend, etc.), claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products. 
When a user does not have access permission to a feature, the system hides or disables that part 
of the application.

HealthRules: Configuration Entities (1/3)
EntityDescription
HCC ( HealthCare 
Company )
The health care company (HCC) is the highest-level entity in the HealthRules 
Healthcare Business Model. The health care company serves as the central 
repository for company-wide demographic information, operational rules and 
provisions, reimbursement rules for non-participating providers, and definitions. 
For some operational provisions and definitions, the values set at the HCC level 
can be overridden at lower levels.
Sub CompanySub-company is optional and used when customer needs to segment their 
business for govt mandate or reporting purpose.
Line of Business 
Group (LOB)
Primary used to group products with product types (HMO, PPO, Medicare etc.) 
or business types (Retiree, Active, ASO, etc.)
LOB GroupUsually used for reporting purpose. Can be created as Product type, business 
type LOB groups.
ProductProducts are marketed offering of the health plans. Some rules and entities that

LOB GroupUsually used for reporting purpose. Can be created as Product type, business 
type LOB groups.
ProductProducts are marketed offering of the health plans. Some rules and entities that 
are part of HCC also can be configured in product to override HCC rules. Payment 
Cycle, Bank Account, Non Par Payment rule etc. The benefits are not configured 
in product but configured in Benefit Plan.
Benefit PlanThe Benefit plan corresponds to the real-world contract between account and 
HCC. This defines the benefits available to the employee/member of the account

26
HealthRules: Configuration Entities (2/3)
EntityDescription
Benefit Plan 
Components
Benefit Plan Components (BPC) is an HRL document holding collection of related 
business rules governing benefits, limits, exclusions, maximums, deductible, 
utilization requirements etc.
Service CategoryA service category is a named service definitions. Service categories are  created 
using Health Rules Language. Service categories are primary mechanism to 
define the benefits and can be used across different benefit components.
Value ListThese HRL document contains values for the placeholder variables that can be 
referenced in BPC.  Example: Variable “PCP Copay” has value $10
Network 
Definition
These HRL document contains definition of provider networks and service areas 
that can be selected for use in a particular benefit structure.
Benefit NetworkA Benefit network is a group of providers who are considered in network for

that can be selected for use in a particular benefit structure.
Benefit NetworkA Benefit network is a group of providers who are considered in network for 
members of various product. Provider are connected to the Benefit Network via 
Suppliers or Practitioners. Members are connected to benefit network via the 
network tier on their Network Definition (within Benefit Plan)
AccountAn account is usually the purchaser of health insurance (generally an employer 
group). In Medicare, Medicaid or individual business lines the account is used as 
generic umbrella.

27
HealthRules: Configuration Entities (3/3)
EntityDescription
Supplier NetworkSupplier networks are organization that contract on behalf of many suppliers and 
practitioners
SupplierA supplier is an organization that bill for healthcare services. Examples: Hospitals, 
clinics, and labs. Supplier may also render services
Supplier ContractThe Supplier Contract corresponds to the real-world contract between a supplier 
and HCC (Health plans). This contract is a repository for operational provisions 
that applies to the supplier, as well as the pricing details and utilization 
managements. 
PractitionerA Practitioner is an individual who renders healthcare services. Example: 
Physicians, Nurses, Social Workers etc.
Subscription/Me
mber
Members are part of subscription and subscriptions are part of account/or child 
account.

HealthRules: HCC Configuration Rules (1/2)

30
HealthRules: HCC Configuration Rules (2/2)

31
HCC Policies
▪Company wide policies are set on the Health Care Company. There are two types of policies:
CTML Policies:
▪Repair: The problem must be fixed before the transaction can be completed
▪Reject: The transaction will be rejected.
▪Warning: The transaction will go through, and a warning will be placed on the record.
▪Review: The transaction could go through, but will be pended for manual review. No changes 
need to be made to complete transaction.
Processing Policies: 
▪Rules for paying non-participating providers
▪Claim processing rules (Modifier pricing, authorization matching, COB rules, Duplicate Detection, 
etc.)

Account Setup

36
Create Account
▪Access the Create Account window from either of two places:
•Manager Home page Members tab: Account Create link
•HealthRulesManager window File menu: Create > Account
▪In the General tab Account Identity section, 
•specify an account name.
•specify the account ID. If you leave the field empty, and if auto numbering is enabled, the 
system will automatically assign an ID when the account record is saved.
▪Select the Contact tab. In the Primary Correspondence section, enter the postal and email 
addresses for corresponding with the member. To avoid the standard address check, which 
ensures that the postal address exists and is correctly entered, select the Ignore Address Check 
option.
▪Click Save. A Reason Code dialog appears. A reason code must be selected, and optionally a 
comment can be included. 
▪Choose Reason Code Account create, and then click OK. The system validates the data according

comment can be included. 
▪Choose Reason Code Account create, and then click OK. The system validates the data according 
to business rules. If there are no validation errors, the system creates the account and you are 
finished creating the record. If the system does not add the account record, errors appear in the 
audit log. You can either save you work to a workbasket for later review (click the Work In 
Progress button) or correct the errors immediately.
